page.title: Tri-Agency Open Access Policy on Publications

revision.text:
Canada introduced the '''Tri-Agency Open Access Policy on Publications'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Tri-Agency Open Access Policy on Publication.|url=http://www.science.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=F6765465-1|website=Science.gc.ca|publisher=Government of Canada’s oscience portal|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> in May 2015 to mandate open access to research articles funded by Canada's three major research agencies: the [[Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council]]<ref>{{cite web|title=NSERC - Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada|url=http://www.nserc-crsng.gc.ca/index_eng.asp|website=Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> (NSERC), the [[Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council|url=http://www.sshrc-crsh.gc.ca/home-accueil-eng.aspx|website=Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> (SSHRC) and the [[Canadian Institutes of Health Research]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Canadian Institutes of Health Research|url=http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/193.html|website=Canadian Institutes of Health Research|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> (CIHR). CIHR has had an open access policy<ref>{{cite web|title=CIHR Open Access Policy|url=http://www.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/e/46068.html|website=Canadian Institutes of Health Research|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref> since 2008 and the new Tri-Agency policy is largely based on CIHR's pre-existing policy.
The policy stipulates that peer-reviewed journal articles produced from funded research must be made [[open access]] within 12 months of publication by either: *publication in an [[open access journal]] *archiving in a [[subject repository]] or [[institutional repository]]
== Applicability == The policy affects Tri-Agency grants awarded on or after May 1, 2015. All funded researchers are affected except graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Only peer-reviewed journal articles are covered by the policy: other research outputs such as books or media, are not affected. Only [[postprints]] or final published articles may be archived in a subject or institutional repository; other article versions, e.g. [[preprints]], are not acceptable.<ref name="TriAgencyFAQ">{{cite web|title=Tri-Agency Open Access Policy on Publications: Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.science.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=A30EBB24-1|website=Science.gc.ca|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref>
== Compliance == Enforcement of the Tri-Agency policy has not been explicitly described. Compliance with the CIHR open access policy has been managed in conjunction with the Research Reporting Service.<ref name="TriAgencyFAQ" />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Open access (publishing)]]

{{for|UBIT|Unrelated Business Income Tax}}
In [[quantum mechanics]], the '''u-bit''' or '''ubit''' is a proposed theoretical entity which arises in attempts to reformulate [[wave functions]] using only [[real number]]s instead of the [[complex number]]s conventionally used.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Aleksandrova |first1=Antoniya |last2=Borish |first2=Victoria |last3=Wootters |first3=William K. |journal=[[Physical Review A]] |title=Real-vector-space quantum theory with a universal quantum bit |date=May 7, 2013 |volume=87 |issue=5 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.87.052106 |arxiv = 1210.4535 |bibcode = 2013PhRvA..87e2106A }}</ref>
== Description == In order to discover the real probability of a given quantum event occurring, the conventional calculation carries out an operation, analogous to squaring, on an associated set of complex numbers. A complex number involves the use of the [[square root of minus one]], a number which is described as "[[imaginary number|imaginary]]" in contrast to the familiar "[[Real numbers|real" numbers]] used for counting and describing real physical objects. Because the computed result is required to be a real number, information is lost in the computation.<ref>[http://pitp.ca/fr/videos/ubit-model-real-vector-space-quantum-theory The Ubit Model In Real-Vector-Space Quantum Theory] (2012) Lecture by William Wootters at the Institut Périmètre de Physique Théorique , Canada. Accessed Jan 2014</ref>
This situation is regarded as unsatisfactory by some researchers, who seek an alternative formulation which does not involve the square root of minus one. [[Bill Wootters]], of [[Williams College]], [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]], and colleagues have derived such a model. This model requires the presence of a universal entity which is [[Quantum entangled|quantum-entangled]] with every quantum wave and which he calls the u-bit.<ref name="ns25012014">{{cite news |last=Chalmers |first=Matthew |magazine=[[New Scientist]] |title=From i to u: Searching for the quantum master bit |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22129530.700-from-i-to-u-searching-for-the-quantum-master-bit.html |date=January 25, 2014 |accessdate=February 14, 2014 |pages=32–35}}</ref>
Mathematically the u-bit may be represented as a [[Vector (mathematics and physics)|vector]] rotating in a real two-dimensional plane. It has no known physical representation in the real world.<ref name="ns25012014" />
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Quantum mechanics]] [[Category:Real numbers]] [[Category:Fringe physics]]

In [[Semiconductor device fabrication|semiconductor manufacturing]], '''virtual metrology''' refers to methods to predict the properties of a [[Wafer (electronics)|wafer]] based on machine parameters and sensor data in the production equipment, without performing the (costly) physical measurement of the wafer properties. Statistical methods such as classification and regression are used to perform such a task.
Examples of virtual metrology include: * the prediction of the silicon nitride (<math>Si_3 N_4</math>) layer thickness in the [[Chemical vapor deposition|chemical vapor deposition process]] (CVD), using [[multivariate regression]] methods;<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1109/TMECH.2013.2273435 |title=Regression Methods for Virtual Metrology of Layer Thickness in Chemical Vapor Deposition |year=2014 |last1=Purwins |first1=Hendrik |last2=Bernd |first2=Barak |last3=Nagi |first3=Ahmed | last4=Engel |first4=Reiner | last5=Hoeckele |first5=Uwe | last6=Kyek |first6=Andreas | last7=Cherla |first7=Srikanth | last8=Lenz |first8=Benjamin | last9=Pfeifer |first9=Guenther | last10=Weinzierl |first10=Kurt|journal=IEEE - ASME Transactions on Mechatronics |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=1–8}}</ref> * the prediction of critical dimension in [[photolithography]], using multi-level and [[Regularization (mathematics)|regularization]] approaches;<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Susto|first=Gian Antonio|last2=Pampuri|first2=Simone|last3=Schirru|first3=Andrea|last4=Beghi|first4=Alessandro|last5=De Nicolao|first5=Giuseppe|date=2015-01-01|title=Multi-step virtual metrology for semiconductor manufacturing: A multilevel and regularization methods-based approach|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305054814001373|journal=Computers & Operations Research|volume=53|pages=328–337|doi=10.1016/j.cor.2014.05.008}}</ref> * the prediction of layer width in [[Etching (microfabrication)|etching]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Susto|first=G. A.|last2=Johnston|first2=A. B.|last3=O'Hara|first3=P. G.|last4=McLoone|first4=S.|date=2013-08-01|title=Virtual metrology enabled early stage prediction for enhanced control of multi-stage fabrication processes|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6653980/?arnumber=6653980|journal=2013 IEEE International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE)|pages=201–206|doi=10.1109/CoASE.2013.6653980}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Semiconductor device fabrication]] [[Category:Automation]] [[Category:Lithography (microfabrication)]] [[Category:Metrology]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{cleanup|date=January 2011}} {{refimprove|date=January 2011}} }} {{Infobox telescope}}
The Warkworth 12m Radio Telescope<ref>Gulyaev, S., Natusch, T., "Introducing the AUT 12m Radio Telescope". Southern Stars, 47 (1), 2008.</ref> at the [[Warkworth Radio Astronomical Observatory]] is operated by the [http://irasr.aut.ac.nz/ Institute of Radio Astronomy and Space Research] of [[Auckland University of Technology]]. It was constructed in 2008<ref>Gulyaev, S., Natusch, T., "New Zealand 12-m VLBI Station for Geodesy and Astronomy". IVS 2008 Annual Report, 2008.</ref><ref>D., Dickey, 9 October 2008, Rodney Times,p.11, A first for NZ, New Zealand's first professional radio telescope was officially opened yesterday at Satellite Station Rd in Warkworth.</ref><ref>D., Dickey, 16 October 2008,p.5, Rodney Times, Science fiction becomes reality, The Telecom satellite station south of Warkworth held the official opening of the new radio telescope on 8 October.</ref> and is located just south of [[Warkworth, New Zealand|Warkworth]] off SH1 about 50 km north of [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]].
==Technical information== 12m diameter antenna designed and constructed by [http://www.cobham.com/ COBHAM Satcom, Patriot Products division].
Antenna type : Fully steerable dual shaped [[Cassegrain reflector|Cassegrain]] Main dish Diam : 12.1 m Secondary Refl Diam : 1.8m Focal Length : 4.538 m Surface precision : 0.35 mm (RMS) Pointing accuracy : 18" Wavelength : [[L-Band]], [[s band|S-Band]] and [[X-Band]] Mount : alt-azimuth Slewing rates : (5 deg/s in azimuth and 1.25 deg/s in elevation) Acceleration : (1.3 deg/s/s)
Dual polarization S and X-band feeds from COBHAM with room temperature receivers, the receiver systems cover 2.2 to 2.4 GHz at S-band and 8.1 to 9.1 GHz at X-band.
==Research activity== In 2010 this dish was used for several [[Very Long Baseline Interferometry]] observations<ref>Tzioumis et al, Evolution of the pc-scale structure of PKS 1934-638 revisited: first science with the ASKAP and New Zealand telescopes, The Astronomical Journal 140 (2010) 1506-1510</ref><ref>{{cite journal| arxiv=1012.4243| author1=Leonid Petrov| author2=Chris Phillips| author3=Tasso Tzioumis| author4=Bruce Stansby| author5=Cormac Reynolds| author6=Hayley Bignall| author7=Sergei Gulyaev| author8=Tim Natusch| author9=Neville Palmer| title=First geodetic observations using new VLBI stations ASKAP-29 and WARK12M| date=2010| doi=10.1071/AS10048| volume=28| journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of Australia| pages=107–116|bibcode = 2011PASA...28..107P }}</ref> as part of the Australian Long Baseline Array.<ref>{{cite web | title=VLBI and the Australian Long Baseline Array | url=http://www.atnf.csiro.au/vlbi/}}</ref>
It will also from 2011 be part of the International VLBI Service for [[Geodesy]] and [[Astrometry]].<ref>{{cite web | title=International VLBI Service for Geodesy and Astrometry (IVS) | url=http://www.iers.org/SharedDocs/OrganisationalUnit/IVS.html/}}</ref> As such, it is also co-located with a [[Land Information New Zealand|LINZ]]/[[GNS Science|GeoNet]] 'PositioNZ' [[GNSS]] <ref>{{cite web | title=PositioNZ | url=http://apps.linz.govt.nz/positionz/}}</ref> station to help future inclusion in the definition of the International Terrestrial Reference Frame ([[International Terrestrial Reference Frame|ITRF]]).
